Rock physics

Models

We support the following rock physics models to obtain the electrical conductivity of the rock:

Minerals

  • SEO3 : Constable, 2006 : SEO3: A new model of olivine electrical conductivity
  • UHO2014 : Gardés et al., 2014 : Toward a unified hydrous olivine electrical conductivity law
  • Jones2012 : Jones et al., 2012 : Calibrating laboratory-determined models of electrical conductivity of mantle minerals using geophysical and petrological observations
  • Poe2010 : Poe et al., 2010 : Electrical conductivity anisotropy of dry and hydrous olivine at 8GPa
  • Wang2006 : Wang et al., 2006 : The effect of water on the electrical conductivity of olivine
  • Yoshino2009 : Yoshino et al., 2009 :The effect of water on the electrical conductivity of olivine aggregates and its implications for the electrical structure of the upper mantle
  • const_matrix : The solid matrix is assumed to be of constant bulk conductivity

Melt

  • Ni2011 : Ni et al., 2011 : Electrical conductivity of hydrous basaltic melts: implications for partial melting in the upper mantle
  • Sifre2014 : Sifre et al., 2014 : Electrical conductivity during incipient melting in the oceanic low-velocity zone
  • Gaillard2008 : Gaillard et al., 2008 : Carbonatite Melts and Electrical Conductivity in the Asthenosphere

Forward calculations

Forward calculations are fairly easy and involve calling forward function on the model. Following is an example on how we can get the conductivity using Poe2010:

using MT
model_poe = Poe2010(1000 + 273., 2e4)

log_cond = forward(model_poe, [])

Mixing phases

We can also mix in melt and use the following mixing schemes to get the bulk conductivity:

  • HS1962_plus : Hashim-Strikman upper bound for 2 phases
  • HS1962_minus : Hashim-Strikman lower bound for 2 phases
  • MAL : Modified Archie's law
  • single_phase : Bulk rock is composed of one material

Below we estimate the bulk conductivity of rock with solid phase conductivity governed by SEO3 and melt by Ni2011. We'll assume a porosity of 0.1 and calculate the upper HS bounds for the matrix. 


mix1 = construct_mixing_models([1000 + 273., 2e4], [:T, :Ch2o_m],
    [0.1], [SEO3, Ni2011], [HS1962_plus()])

log_cond_mix = forward(mix1, [])

Note:

Note

Even when you have a single phase, the use of construct_mixing_models is recommended using single_phase mixing scheme. Make sure to then have ϕ = 1..


mix_single = construct_mixing_models([1000 + 273., 2e4], [:T, :Ch2o_ol],
    [1.], [UHO2014], [single_phase()])

log_cond = forward(mix_single, [])

Stochastic inversion

Now that we know how to compute the rock physics responses, we move towards performing stochastic inversion for rock physics parameters given some rock conductivity and the corresponding uncertainty.s

using Distributions
using StatsPlots
using Turing
# define a rock physics distribution to sample parameters from
m_dist = RockphyModelDistribution(
    Product([
        Uniform(1173., 1573.),
        Uniform(1e2, 3e4),
    ]),
    [:T, :Ch2o_m],
    Product([Uniform(0.,0.4)]),
    [SEO3, Ni2011],
    [HS1962_plus()]
)

RockphyModelDistribution allows us to define the a priori distribution for rock physics parameters. If the user wants to keep a certain parameter constant, they should define the range of a priori distribution as very small, eg., if, in the above, we want to keep water content in melt CH2o_m constant, we define it's a apriori as a narrow range as

m_dist = RockphyModelDistribution(
    Product([
        Uniform(1173., 1573.),
        Uniform(2e4-1, 2e4+1), # Keeping Ch2o_m almost fix around 2e4
    ]),
    [:T, :Ch2o_m],
    Product([Uniform(0.,0.4)]),
    [SEO3, Ni2011],
    [HS1962_plus()]
)
r_dist = RockphyResponseDistribution((x,y) -> MultivariateNormal(x,y))

m_cache = mcmc_cache(
    m_dist,
    r_dist,
    50_000,
    MH()
)

# rock physics response
rp_obs = RockphyCond(log_cond_mix.σ)
err_rp = RockphyCond(log_cond_mix.σ .* 0.01)

samples = stochastic_inverse(rp_obs, err_rp, [], m_cache) #, trans_utils=(m=log_tf,))

plot(samples)
